newsitem.title: USA: US Court rules against CFTC on forex options trade.
newsitem.headline: US Court rules against CFTC on forex options trade.

text.p: A unanimous U.S. Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that Congress has not authorized the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to regulate "off-exchange" trading in options to buy or sell foreign currency.

At issue in the ruling was the so-called "Treasury Amendment" adopted by Congress in 1974 to the Commodity Exchange Act. The section says the CFTC does not have jurisdiction over foreign currency transactions "unless they involve sales for future delivery on a board of trade."
"The Treasury Amendment exempts from CFTC regulation off- exchange trading in foreign currency options," Justice John Paul Stevens declared in the high court's ruling.

The case began when CFTC had filed suit in New York, charging William Dunn, Delta Consultants, a New Jersey firm he headed, and two other companies he was associated with, with fraud in connection with commodity option transactions.
The alleged scheme involved call and put options on various foreign currencies that were traded among dealers and brokers, not on any organized exchange.
A federal judge in 1994 granted the CFTC's request for the appointment of a temporary receiver to locate and take control of the defendants' funds.

The CFTC cited the apparent disappearance of more than $180 million in customer funds and the transfer by the defendants from the United States to Switzerland of at least $19.5 million just before the alleged scheme was discovered.
A U.S. Court of Appeals rejected a challenge by Dunn and Delta Consultants claiming the CFTC lacked jurisdiction over the dispute.
But the Supreme Court reversed the appeals court's decision.
Stevens said it was plain that foreign currency options are "transactions in foreign currency" within the meaning of the law.

He said the Supreme Court was not persuaded by any of the arguments advanced by the CFTC in support of a narrower reading of the law that would exempt from its regulation certain futures contracts without exempting options.
The CFTC and the U.S. Treasury Department have adopted differing views about the scope of the law.

Supporting the appeal by Dunn and Delta Consultants were a number of industry trade groups, including the Futures Industry Association, the Managed Futures Association and the Public Securities Association.

They said the appeals court's decision "creates significant uncertainty over the enforceability of the United States's half of the $40 billion in foreign currency options transactions traded daily." They also said the ruling imposes "tremendous regulatory and transactional costs" on the over-the-counter foreign exchange markets.
On the other side, Chicago futures exchanges said they could be put out of business by unregulated competitors if the high court throws out the CFTC's case against Dunn.

Stevens concluded that arguments by each side on whether off-exchange foreign currency options should be exempt from CFTC regulation represented "an important public policy" question best addressed by Congress, not the courts.
Several members of Congress have said they may push for the adoption of legislation to change the 1974 amendment.
